alert.note: Alert for Cheyenne; Kit Carson County; Yuma (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Goodland (Northwestern Kansas and East Central Colorado)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued December 02 at 3:31AM MST until December 02 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Goodland
info.description: ...Red Flag Warning Continues For Northeast Colorado and Northwest Kansas... .A combination of warm temperatures, low RH values and windy conditions will lead to explosive fire weather conditions today. Gusty westerly winds will be present across the warning area before shifting to the NW behind a cold front during the afternoon; winds will become stronger behind the cold front gusting 55-65 mph. Blowing dust is expected during the afternoon with perhaps a wall of dust along the cold front. ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 5 PM MST THIS AFTERNOON FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 001, 002, 003, 004, 013, 014, 015, 016, 027, 028, 029, 041, 042, 252, 253, AND 254... * Affected Area...In Colorado, Fire Weather Zone 252 Yuma, Fire Weather Zone 253 Kit Carson and Fire Weather Zone 254 Cheyenne. In Kansas, Fire Weather Zone 001 Cheyenne, Fire Weather Zone 002 Rawlins, Fire Weather Zone 003 Decatur, Fire Weather Zone 004 Norton, Fire Weather Zone 013 Sherman, Fire Weather Zone 014 Thomas, Fire Weather Zone 015 Sheridan, Fire Weather Zone 016 Graham, Fire Weather Zone 027 Wallace, Fire Weather Zone 028 Logan, Fire Weather Zone 029 Gove, Fire Weather Zone 041 Greeley and Fire Weather Zone 042 Wichita. * Winds...Westerly 20-30 mph gusting up to 45 mph becoming Northwest 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 65 mph. * Relative Humidity...Around 14 percent. * Impacts...Any fires that start will have extreme to explosive fire growth and behavior. Outdoor burning is not advised. The wind shift and blowing dust would create a potentially dangerous situation to first responders if a fire were to be ongoing.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now...or are imminent. A combination of strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.
